author: By Sarah Frier
title: Big Tech Is Embracing Trump. How Long Will It Last?
description: Three new books explore the fraught relationships between tech companies and the U.S. government through close looks at Jeff Bezos’ Amazon and Elon Musk’s X.
content: Elon Musk wasn’t always such a big fan of Donald Trump. In December 2016, he reluctantly joined Trump’s business advisory council, only to leave it a few months later after the Republican president pulled out of an international climate agreement. Trump also played hot and cold with the tech industry. During his first term in office, he was generally critical of Big Tech tycoons and their power, even as critics lined up to argue that social media platforms, exploited by foreign agents and hyper-political outlets, had helped deliver him to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: How to Turn Up the Heat on Your Mulled Cocktails
description: A mulled white wine made with coriander, fennel and elderflower liqueur, a punchy nonalcoholic mulled cider, and mulled beer fortified with Cognac will make the season bright.
content: Cold weather makes a near universal case for hot drinks. Add in a festive season and mulled wine quickly enters the chat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an Irish drama about a pirate-queen, a found-footage movie made from lost Palestinian films, a coming-of-age thriller from Mexico and more.
content: Shot on 16 mm and drenched in aquamarine hues, the new film by Donal Foreman is a lovely and unclassifiable thing. Two women — an American filmmaker, Maire (Dale Dickey) and an Irish scholar, Cait (Judith Roddy) — go to a remote Irish island to make a film about a 16th-century pirate-queen, and are drawn into the shifting sands of reality and fiction, myth and history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Tell Us: What’s Your Favorite Movie About Politics?
description: Share your pick with the On Politics newsletter.
content: You might be tired of politics after this roller coaster of a presidential election. Maybe you’ve tried escaping to the movies — only to find that some of the season’s marquee releases, like “Gladiator II” or the Ralph Fiennes pope thriller “Conclave,” are themselves about campaigns, conniving and democracy’s viability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meher Ahmad and Vishakha Darbha
title: Tell Us What Brought You Joy in 2024
description: Where did you find comfort, joy, fun or just distraction this year?
content: Is there a movie, a book, a meme, a memory, a hobby you took up or a vice you quit that stayed with you this year, or helped you unwind and forget about everything else? Times Opinion wants to hear about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Trump Backs Dockworkers in Dispute Over Automation
description: The president-elect’s intervention could help the longshoremen’s union win concessions and avoid the resumption of a strike on East and Gulf Coast ports.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Thursday offered his support to a union representing dockworkers at East and Gulf Coast ports that is negotiating a new labor contract. His intervention could help the union win concessions from the companies that operate port terminals and avoid the resumption of a strike that was suspended in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: efficient
description: This word has appeared in 1,694 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word efficient has appeared in 1,694 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 19 in “Through the Turnstile and Down the Aisle” by Sarah Lyon:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a sequel to a 1980s Tim Burton classic and an animated tale of a Christmas nearly gone wrong.
content: One of the joys of parenthood is introducing your child to classic films that you once loved. It thrills me that my 7-year-old son adores “E.T.” and the original “Star Wars” and “Indiana Jones” films. Watching him mimic the “Banana Boat (Day-O)” dance in Tim Burton’s 1988 goth horror comedy “Beetlejuice” has been one of the highlights of my year. For older children that love scary-ish movies, Burton’s long-awaited follow-up film is a kooky medley of wacky scares and outrageous scenarios. Winona Ryder returns as a grown-up Lydia. She’s now a widow who hosts a ghost show on TV, and her goth teenage daughter, Astrid (Jenna Ortega), is every bit as brooding as her mother was at her age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: McConnell Defends Polio Vaccine, an Apparent Warning to Kennedy
description: “Efforts to undermine public confidence in proven cures are not just uninformed — they’re dangerous,” said the Republican leader, who is a polio survivor.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader and a survivor of polio, issued a pointed statement in support of the polio vaccine on Friday, hours after The New York Times reported that the lawyer for Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has petitioned federal regulators to withdraw the vaccine from the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 36 Things That Stuck With Us in 2024
description: The movie scenes, TV episodes, song lyrics and other moments that reporters, critics, editors and visual journalists in Culture couldn’t stop thinking about this year.
content: Real tennis, like real dancing, happens when the body is rapt and alive, where visceral sensation takes over and the only thing left is the crystallization of every nerve and muscle, both aligned and on edge. That last match was a dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aryn Baker
title: What Is Captagon, the Illegal Stimulant That Made al-Assad’s Syria a Narcostate?
description: The illegal amphetamine, used across the Middle East, became Syria’s biggest export during its 13-year civil war.
content: Rebel fighters in Syria said on Friday that they had found vast stockpiles of an illegal amphetamine called captagon in a Damascus warehouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Josephs
title: Move Over, Charlie Brown: Lessons From ‘The Boondocks’ Christmas Special
description: With “A Huey Freeman Christmas,” the show continued what “A Charlie Brown Christmas” began: acknowledging the weight of the holiday.
content: One of the most beloved holiday traditions that doesn’t involve gift-giving is “A Charlie Brown Christmas.” The 1965 animated special, depicting the trials of the titular sad sack and a crew of kids wearied beyond their years by commercialism, has inspired repeat viewings and countless appraisals, including in The New York Times. But the genre of Christmas specials it inspired, including “How the Grinch Stole Christmas!” and “Frosty the Snowman,” largely leaned away from Charlie’s melancholy and toward a wholesome belief in the righteous power of the holiday spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: What to Know About ‘The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim’
description: You don’t have to know an orc from a Mumakil to enjoy the new animated adventure, though it’ll certainly help.
content: If you would like to know who the Helm of Helm’s Deep is, you are in the right place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Fed Is Stuck Fighting the Last War
description: Mired in a battle to contain surging prices, the central bank also needs to be nimble enough for the economic downturns to come, our columnist says.
content: The battle against inflation during the Biden years is almost behind us. But we’re in danger of learning the wrong lessons from it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Shayla Colon
title: F.B.I. Passed Tip About Mangione to New York Police After C.E.O. Killing
description: It was unclear when the information arrived, or whether it would have helped speed an arrest in the death of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare.
content: Investigators received a tip from the San Francisco Police Department identifying Luigi Mangione as a suspect before he was arrested in the killing of an insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan, the New York F.B.I. field office said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: Can Berlin Really Afford 3 ‘Magic Flutes’ in a Single Week?
description: Each of the city’s opera houses is presenting a different production of the Mozart classic. With arts cuts looming, it looks like a last hurrah.
content: Opera has always tended toward grandeur. Berlin, home to three world-class opera houses, regularly takes things to the next level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: The Fall of al-Assad Quickly Infuses Europe’s Debate Over Asylum
description: Nearly a million Syrians in Germany alone have made new lives. But after the fall of Bashar al-Assad, some politicians across the continent have suggested that refugees could return home.
content: Just hours after President Bashar al-Assad boarded a plane for Russia on Sunday, thousands of Syrians who had fled to escape his rule and the civil war to unseat him celebrated in the streets across Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Tripp Mickle
title: Tim Cook Dines With Trump at Mar-a-Lago
description: The chief executive of Apple is the latest in a series of technology  executives who are traveling to Florida to meet with the president-elect.
content: Tim Cook held a meeting on Friday with Donald J. Trump at Mar-a-Lago, marking the first time that Apple’s chief executive has met with the president-elect since voters elected him to a second term last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Catholic Charity’s Bid for Tax Exemption
description: The justices agreed to hear an appeal from a Wisconsin Supreme Court ruling that the charity’s activities were insufficiently religious to qualify.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether Wisconsin was free to deny a tax exemption to a Catholic charity on the grounds that its activities were not primarily religious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Nicole Tung
title: With al-Assad Gone, Syrians Seek Answers in an Underground Jail
description: Guided by cellphone flashlights, relatives searched a notorious lockup in Damascus for traces of loved ones who were snatched during the regime of Bashar al-Assad.
content: Her brother was pulled from his car at a military checkpoint nearly a decade ago, her brother-in-law dragged from his house by the police. Two of her cousins were arrested near the airport in the Syrian capital, Damascus. She said she never had heard from any of them again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Harris to Deliver Speech Urging Young People to Stay Civically Engaged
description: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has kept a relatively low profile since she lost the election, will speak in Maryland on Tuesday.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has kept a low profile since she lost the presidential election, will give a speech in Maryland next week urging young people to stay civically engaged, the White House announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller
title: The Under-the-Radar Filipino Island That Evokes 1970s Bali
description: A guide to Siargao, a surf spot turned luxury escape, with insider tips on where to find powdery beaches and coconut slushies.
content: Spend a few days in Siargao, the fig-shaped Filipino island in the country’s southeast, and locals will tell you, with a mix of anxiety and excitement, that the coconut tree-covered enclave is what Bali was in the 1970s. Or they might say, as the documentarian and trans-rights activist Queenmelo Esguerra told me last month, that laid-back hotels and cafes that’ve opened this decade (like Siago), “feel inspired by Tulum, no?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: How the Wackiest, Most ‘Annoying’ Christmas Song Became a Hit
description: It started with a novelty songwriter stranded on a snowy night. Decades later, listeners still can’t get his tune, “Grandma Got Run Over By a Reindeer,” out of their heads.
content: On a cold and snowy night in November 1978, the members of Randy Brooks’s country band, Young Country, found themselves stranded after a gig at the Hyatt Hotel on the Nevada side of Lake Tahoe. The brakes on their van were frozen. With nowhere to go, Mr. Brooks and his bandmates went back inside to watch the next act, a bluegrass group fronted by the husband-and-wife duo of Elmo Shropshire and Patsy Trigg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Coral Davenport
title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to California Tailpipe Emissions Limits
description: The justices agreed to decide whether industry groups have suffered the sort of injury that gave them standing to sue over an unusual waiver.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to consider whether business groups may challenge an unusual federal program that lets California set its own limits on tailpipe emissions to combat climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rodney Jenkins, Star of the Show-Jumping Circuit, Dies at 80
description: He had a feel for how horses behaved and thought, and he won more than 70 Grand Prix events before retiring to train racehorses.
content: Rodney Jenkins, an equestrian who dominated shows in the 1970s and ’80s by deftly guiding horses in competition with a rare feel for their abilities and thoughts, died on Dec. 5 at his home in Maryland. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: What ‘Wicked’ Has to Say About Our Current Political Moment
description: By breaking the story into two movies, the emphasis in “Part One” shifts to a nation’s potential decline into authoritarianism. Sound familiar?
content: In the big-screen adaptation of “Wicked,” Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo) uses magic to defend her sister and unwittingly destroys a courtyard mural of the Wizard at Shiz University. When her outburst shatters the wall, it also unearths an image that has been intentionally covered up: the school’s original founders, animal professors whose ability to speak, teach humans, and organize politically posed a threat to the Wizard’s autocratic reign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: It’s Going to Be Normal to Have Extreme Beliefs
description: What the fascination with a C.E.O.’s killing reveals about this political era.
content: I promise not to make every installment of this newsletter a further elaboration on what it means to live after the post-Cold War liberal order, in a world where a certain kind of neoliberal consensus politics has dissolved without any new consensus sweeping in to take its place. But I’ll go once more to the well for the case of Luigi Mangione, who has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, Brian Thompson, and who has become a source of general fascination and, to some, a peculiar kind of outlaw hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Maggie Haberman
title: Amazon Plans $1 Million Donation to Trump’s Inaugural Fund
description: The move follows Meta’s donation of the same amount to the fund earlier this week.
content: Amazon said on Thursday that it was planning to donate $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, part of a pattern in which tech companies and their leaders are taking steps to repair their relationships with Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leia Larsen and Kim Raff
title: In a Growing Utah City, Residents Are Turning Against Their Mayor
description: Residents voted to rein in a mayor who they say has a penchant for secrecy and is overly deferential to developers.
content: Residents say Julie Fullmer was the type of mayor who would give out her cellphone number, responding to complaints at all hours about unplowed snow routes or broken sprinklers. She regularly encouraged residents, especially women, to run for City Council and volunteer on boards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak and Pat Kane
title: Gas Could Mean Billions for Indigenous People in Canada. Some Fear a Cost.
description: New export terminals along the rugged Pacific coastline have reignited a generations-old debate over identity and environmental stewardship.
content: With her hair pulled back into a tight ponytail, her arms and legs covered with 20 tattoos, and her compact frame fitted out in athleisure, Crystal Smith, the elected chief of the Haisla people, looked more like the hometown basketball star she once was than the fossil fuel exporter she’s about to become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: What We Know About Reports of Drone Sightings in New Jersey and New York
description: Reports of flying objects continue to occur throughout the region. State and local officials say they do not pose a threat but have provided few answers.
content: Bright lights floating or flying in the night sky above New Jersey have captivated residents for nearly a month. Now the sightings, which many observers believe to be drones, have spread throughout the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Exploring the Brazil Where Schnapps and Grappa Flow
description: A road trip through Brazil’s Rio Grande do Sul state leads to German and Italian cuisine, dialects and a surprising number of music festivals.
content: I had intricately planned my road trip exploring the Italian and German heritage of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil’s southernmost state, to maximize immigrant cuisine, unsung wineries and villages with charming timber-frame buildings. I’d visit Antônio Prado, the self-proclaimed “most Italian city in Brazil,” drive along rural roads lined with hydrangeas, and explore Gramado, a town whose center this time of year resembles an Epcot version of an Alpine ski town, decked out with Santa statues and massive candy canes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Jerome Kohn, Keeper of Hannah Arendt’s Flame, Dies at 93
description: He devoted his career to guarding the legacy of the philosopher known for her writings on totalitarianism and “the banality of evil.”
content: Jerome Kohn, who devoted his career to decoding, defending and disseminating the work of Hannah Arendt, the provocative philosopher who diagnosed the roots of 20th-century totalitarianism and controvertibly wrote that the convicted Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann embodied “the banality of evil,” died on Nov. 8 in Bay Shore, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Time’s Person of the Year Doesn’t Surprise Late Night Hosts
description: “Trump is the first man in history to be Time’s person of the year and McDonald’s employee of the month,” Jimmy Fallon said on Thursday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Hochul Launches Investigation Into Drone Sightings in New York
description: The governor made the announcement on Friday as sightings spread across New York and New Jersey. State and federal authorities said the flying objects posed no threat to the public.
content: As reports of drone sightings continued to spread across New Jersey and New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Friday said she was investigating the matter with federal law enforcement agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lana Bortolot
title: $3 Million Homes in the Caribbean
description: A villa-guest cottage combo and a sleek contemporary house in Barbados, and a luxury bungalow in the Bahamas.
content: Situated in the private island resort of Kamalame Cay, which occupies a 96-acre cay off the northeast coast of the Bahamas’ largest island, this three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath home features vaulted ceilings and an indoor-outdoor layout. Andros Island is home to the Andros Barrier Reef, which stretches 124 miles. This house sits on a split of land — a cay is a low-elevation island on the surface of a reef. One side faces a white-sand beach and the Atlantic Ocean, and on the other side faces salt marshes and the mainland. The resort community is 14 miles from Andros Town, the island’s capital and home to Andros Town International Airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: A Bagel Shop Closed, and the Upper West Side Is Absolutely Losing It
description: The neighborhood reaction to the sudden closure of a Manhattan bagel shop was intense: “No no no no no no no no no no no!!”
content: In the vast constellation of New York City bagel shops, Absolute Bagels on the Upper West Side has held a lofty but unusual position of honor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Gillibrand Presses Biden to Amend the Constitution to Enshrine Sex Equality
description: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York is leading the charge for Democrats to persuade President Biden to adopt the Equal Rights Amendment, which would invite a Supreme Court battle.
content: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York is on a mission in President Biden’s final days in office. She wants to convince him that he can rescue his legacy by adding the century-old Equal Rights Amendment, which would explicitly guarantee sex equality, to the Constitution as a way to protect abortion rights in post-Roe America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Heffernan
title: This Year, Make Your Own Festivus Pole
description: After an appearance on “Seinfeld” in 1997, the pole took on a life of its own as the embodiment of the anti-holiday spirit.
content: Let’s make a Festivus pole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe
title: McKinsey to Pay $650 Million in Opioid Settlement With Justice Department
description: A former senior partner will also plead guilty to obstruction of justice after destroying company documents.
content: McKinsey & Company has agreed to pay $650 million to settle a Justice Department investigation of its work with the opioid maker Purdue Pharma. A former senior partner has also agreed to plead guilty to obstruction of justice for destroying internal company records in connection with that work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 13, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 13, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about government data on recent immigration into the United States referred incorrectly to a figure in the Census Bureau’s estimate of immigration from 2020 to 2023. The bureau estimated that the foreign-born population changed by an average of about 900,000 from 2020 to 2023, not that net migration changed by that amount. (The first category does not take into account the death of foreign-born people already living in the United States; the second one does.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Humpback Whale Sets Record for How Far It Traveled
description: The adult male swam more than 8,000 miles from South America to Africa, most likely in search of a mate, researchers said.
content: A humpback whale set a record by traversing at least three oceans and more than 8,000 miles — most likely in search of a mate, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Mapo Ragù Is an Ideal Wintertime Feast
description: It’s a meat-sauce mashup of Chinese, Korean and Italian cuisine, sweet-salty and fiery all at once, with tangles of braised kale and chewy rice cakes.
content: Good morning. We hit Del Fiore in Rocky Point for late-morning sandwiches, Italian subs from the northeastern reaches of Brookhaven on Long Island, then pushed west along the Washington Spy Trail toward Port Jefferson, Setauket, Nissequogue, thinking about cooking all the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Carry-On’ Review: Travel Nightmares Amplified
description: In this tense thriller, Taron Egerton plays a T.S.A. agent who goes up against an implacable terrorist (Jason Bateman). The man has a funny idea of what he wants to bring on a plane.
content: If you’re a fan of white-knuckle-tension suspense thrillers, you know the debate as to whether or not the 1988 classic “Die Hard” is a Christmas movie. “Carry-On,” directed by the expert technician Jaume Collet-Serra, makes absolutely no bones about being a Christmas movie as it seeks to work your nerves in the “Die Hard” tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Should You Be Able to Copyright a Vibe?
description: One influencer has accused another of copying her aesthetic on social media. Should stealing someone’s vibe be against the law?
content: Have you ever scrolled through Instagram or TikTok and seen two creators whose content looks nearly identical? They have the same look, are wearing the same outfit, are striking the same pose. In short, they have the same vibe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Kraven the Hunter’ Review: A Seriously Silly Movie
description: Aaron Taylor-Johnson’s buff Marvel hero is overshadowed by unabashedly fun villains.
content: Built on brawn, J.C. Chandor’s action sci-fi picture “Kraven the Hunter” is limited by incomprehensible plotting and dodgy one-liners delivered by a cast who seem to be practicing their worst Russian accents. If not for the bevy of anticlimactic fights, “Kraven the Hunter” could be so bad it’s good. Instead, it’s merely another excursion away from the Marvel Cinematic Universe to Sony’s series of defanged comic book villains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats Argue That the 2024 Election Actually Had Its Bright Spots
description: Some leaders have begun to put a sunnier spin on the November outcome by pointing to down-ballot victories — a possible sign that Democrats may not tear down their party after all.
content: For most Democrats, losing to Donald J. Trump was a devastating gut punch that sent them hurtling into the political abyss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Avant Gardner, Troubled Brooklyn Venue, Promises Security Changes in Major Renovation
description: The planned overhaul comes more than a year after two patrons who left the mega-club were found dead nearby.
content: The new chief executive of Avant Gardner, one of Brooklyn’s largest event venues, said the company was overhauling the space and making sweeping security changes. The overhaul comes during a fraught period for the venue, including the deaths of two patrons found nearby last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: U.S. Charges Ex-Syrian Prison Official With Torture
description: The indictment was the second time in a week that the Justice Department announced that it had charged top Syrian officials with human rights abuses.
content: A federal grand jury in Los Angeles charged a former Syrian government official on Thursday with torturing political dissidents at a notorious prison in Damascus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Rebecca F. Elliott
title: Trump’s Treasury Pick Is Poised to Test ‘Three Arrows’ Economic Strategy
description: Scott Bessent’s “3-3-3” plan to stimulate growth, reduce the deficit and expand oil production will soon face economic realities.
content: When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe set out to rejuvenate Japan’s economy more than a decade ago, he laid out a strategy known as the “Three Arrows,” which aimed to banish deflation by easing monetary policy, increasing government spending and restructuring the economy so that it was poised for growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: How Claude Became Tech Insiders’ Chatbot of Choice
description: A.I. insiders are falling for Claude, a chatbot from Anthropic. Is it a passing fad, or a preview of artificial relationships to come?
content: His fans rave about his sensitivity and wit. Some talk to him dozens of times a day — asking for advice about their jobs, their health, their relationships. They entrust him with their secrets, and consult him before making important decisions. Some refer to him as their best friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Bill Belichick Has Stores Cutting the Sleeves Off Sweatshirts
description: Chapel Hill has embraced North Carolina’s hiring of a legendary N.F.L. coach, with “Chapel Bill” shirts and cutoff hoodies.
content: As rumors circulated this week that Bill Belichick could become the new football coach at the University of North Carolina, Jamie Mottram knew that his company needed to be prepared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Collins Jordan
title: Please Let Me Love My Wife
description: Her pronouns changed. Our bond didn’t.
content: Our story never failed to charm at cocktail parties. We were college sweethearts addicted to one another’s company, pen pals while abroad, intellectual soul mates who moved together from Montana to Manhattan, goofy newlyweds who never stopped rooting for each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Witty
title: UnitedHealth Group C.E.O.: The Health Care System Is Flawed. Let’s Fix It.
description: No one would design a system like the one we have. And no one did.
content: As Brian Thompson’s family, friends and colleagues mourn his killing, we are bearing a grief and sadness we will carry for the rest of our lives. Grief for the family he leaves behind. And grief for a brilliant, kind man who was working to make health care better for everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Where Opera Is Still the Center of the Universe
description: There is nothing quite like opening night of Teatro alla Scala in Milan, a temple of opera, for pomp, pageantry and politics.
content: Television reporters stood shoulder to shoulder delivering breathless, minute-by-minute commentary, part of a pack of more than 120 journalists from 10 countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Judge Says Former ByteDance Executive Lied in Suit Against Company
description: A judge said this week that a former executive at ByteDance seemed to have fabricated evidence and submitted false statements in a high-profile 2023 lawsuit against the company.
content: A federal judge in San Francisco said on Thursday that a former executive at ByteDance lied in statements to the court and seemed to have fabricated an important witness in a high-profile case against the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Cult of Love’ Review: We Wish You a Wretched Christmas
description: A hilarious, harrowing holiday gift from Leslye Headland, who brings another unhappy family to Broadway. Zachary Quinto and Shailene Woodley star.
content: Though figgy pudding is on the menu, Evie Dahl has a different Yuletide horror in mind. “Christmas is exactly the time to talk about the things we never talk about,” she tells her reluctant siblings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: For Wild Animals, the Bird Flu Disaster Is Already Here
description: Scientists are concerned that the H5N1 virus could set off another human pandemic. But it is already putting species under pressure in the wild.
content: Every spring, more than 200,000 northern gannets — stocky seabirds with dazzling white feathers — journey to the coast of eastern Canada. There, they blanket oceanside cliffs and rocky outcroppings, breeding in enormous colonies before flying back south for the winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Bank of America Flagged Suspicious Payments to Epstein Only After He Died
description: Senate staff members are urging that Bank of America be investigated for the way it reported payments to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier.
content: When Bank of America alerted financial regulators in 2020 to potentially suspicious payments from Leon Black, the billionaire investor, to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier, the bank was following a routine practice.The bank filed two “suspicious activity reports,” or SARs, which are meant to alert law enforcement to potential criminal activities like money laundering, terrorism financing or sex trafficking. One was filed in February 2020 and the other eight months later, according to a congressional memorandum reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Why Wray’s Resignation May Signal a Shift in F.B.I. Tradition
description: Mr. Wray’s voluntary departure could usher in a new era at the nation’s premier law enforcement agency, one in which the job of director changes with the administration.
content: Christopher A. Wray had considered resigning as F.B.I. director before. More than once, confronted with angry demands from President Donald J. Trump and his allies, he contemplated calling it quits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: She Swapped Her ‘Spinsterlicious Life’ for Him
description: Eleanore Wells loved her single, child-free life so much that she wrote a book about it. Then, at 60, she moved to Australia where she met Anthony Graham.
content: As far as Eleanore S. Wells was concerned, marriage was overrated. She boasted more than 60 years of singledom, and even wrote a memoir, “The Spinsterlicious Life,” as a testament to that belief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: In New York and Paris, Church Organs Return to Life
description: On Palm Sunday five years ago, fire struck two cathedrals: Notre-Dame and St. John the Divine. Both their organs are now restored.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll find out about the return of pipe organs that went silent for five years after fires broke out at their cathedrals. We’ll also look at a mayoral candidate’s proposal for city-owned grocery stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: The Smithsonian Looks at How the Slave Trade Shaped the World
description: “In Slavery’s Wake,” at the National Museum of African American History and Culture, looks beyond the United States to tell a global story.
content: “In Slavery’s Wake,” a new exhibition at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, deals in huge themes and vast numbers. Over four centuries, an estimated 12 million Africans were transported across the ocean on more than 36,000 voyages, an epochal forced migration that reshaped societies on both sides of the Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Sotheby’s Lays Off More Than 100 Staffers as Auction Sales Slump
description: As the high-flying art market has contracted, the company is looking elsewhere, expanding its luxury brand and real estate in New York, Paris and Hong Kong.
content: Sotheby’s laid off more than 100 staff members around the globe this week, roughly 6 percent of its 1,800-person work force. The cutbacks, which came three weeks after the auction house’s major November sales, were part of an effort to improve the company’s financial picture amid shrinking auction revenue. They came despite a recent $1 billion cash infusion from Abu Dhabi’s sovereign wealth fund and investment company, ADQ.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Mount Vernon Police’s Strip Searches Were Unconstitutional, U.S. Says
description: A report by federal prosecutors found that a Westchester County police department violated the Fourth Amendment “on an enormous scale.”
content: Two women, 65 and 75 years old, were taken to a police station in Mount Vernon, N.Y., after a traffic stop in 2020. Officers instructed both women to undress. Then they were told to bend over and cough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Pam Belluck
title: Texas Attorney General Sues New York Doctor for Mailing Abortion Pills
description: The lawsuit appeared to be among the first attempts to stop doctors from mailing the medication to states that ban abortions.
content: The Texas attorney general opened a new front in the contentious battle over access to abortion this week by suing a New York doctor for sending abortion pills into Texas. It appeared to be among the first attempts to stop the mailing of such medication into states that ban abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Elon Musk and DOGE vs. Regulators
description: The billionaire has needled government agencies, armed with potential influence over their budgets. But some of these organizations are also looking into his interests.
content: Elon Musk remains perhaps the most consequential figure in President-elect Donald Trump’s orbit, with a commission for cutting government spending headed by him and Vivek Ramaswamy — widely known by its acronym, DOGE — promising huge reductions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: Who Better to Explore the Mysteries of the Brain Than Werner Herzog?
description: In “Theater of Thought,” he talks to scientists and other experts about consciousness, quantum computing and whether parrots understand human speech.
content: There’s a moment in “Theater of Thought” (in theaters) when Darío Gil, the director of research at IBM, is explaining quantum computing to Werner Herzog, the movie’s director. Standing before a whiteboard, Gil draws some points on spheres to illustrate how qubits work, then proceeds to define the Schrödinger equation. As he talks and writes, the audio grows quieter, and Herzog’s distinctive resonant German accent takes over. “I admit that I literally understand nothing of this, and I assume most of you don’t either,” he intones in voice-over. “But I found it fascinating that this mathematical formula explains the law that draws the subatomic world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: As East Village’s Little India Fades, One Place Keeps Its Lights On
description: Three neighboring South Asian restaurants with string light-filled windows survived for decades. Only one remains as Sixth Street’s “Curry Row” moniker fades.
content: Four windows at the bottom of a brick building in the East Village used to entice passers-by, with string lights and glowing chili peppers as far as the eye could see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The Texas Millennial Trying to Rebrand the Democrats
description: “We can’t bring a policy book to a gunfight,” said Representative Greg Casar of Texas, the incoming chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.
content: Ever since they lost big in November, Democrats have talked about how much their party needs to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Kennedy’s Lawyer Has Asked the F.D.A. to Revoke Approval of the Polio Vaccine
description: Aaron Siri, who specializes in vaccine lawsuits, has been at Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s side reviewing candidates for top jobs at the Department of Health and Human Services.
content: The lawyer helping Robert F. Kennedy Jr. pick federal health officials for the incoming Trump administration has petitioned the government to revoke its approval of the polio vaccine, which for decades has protected millions of people from a virus that can cause paralysis or death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Paula Abdul Settles Sexual Assault Lawsuit Against Nigel Lythgoe
description: Mr. Lythgoe, a producer she worked with on “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance,” had vehemently denied her allegations.
content: Paula Abdul has settled a lawsuit that she filed against Nigel Lythgoe, a television producer, accusing him of sexually assaulting her when they worked together on “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Vanderbilt
title: Looking for Friends? Start With Family.
description: How a brother-in-law became my best friend.
content: Friends, it is often said, are the family you choose. But sometimes, it goes the other way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: Health Protections for Migrant Children in Custody Are Set to Expire
description: A 2022 legal settlement established requirements to protect the health of minors detained at segments of the southern border. It ends nine days after Donald Trump takes office.
content: A court-ordered system for protecting the health of children detained at the southern border, put in place two years ago after several children died in  custody, is set to expire nine days after Donald J. Trump takes office with plans to intensify the deportation of migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Ryan Mac
title: OpenAI Fires Back at Elon Musk’s Lawsuit
description: The artificial intelligence start-up argues that Mr. Musk is trying to hamstring its business as he builds a rival company.
content: Earlier this month, Elon Musk asked a federal court to block OpenAI’s efforts to transform itself from a nonprofit into a purely for-profit company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Would You Buy a Perfume You Had Never Smelled?
description: A half-million people are on the Ffern wait list hoping to do just that.
content: “We have this conviction that fine fragrance is like fine wine,” said Owen Mears, the founder of Ffern, a line of perfumes based in London. “Everybody knows it’s just grapes, but you can’t simply recreate it, because there is craft involved.” He was drinking tea at the Nine Orchard hotel next to his sister, Emily Cameron, Ffern’s creative director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: A New Frontier in Paleontology for Profit: Selling Shares in a Stegosaurus
description: As academics fear being priced out of the fossil market, a private company announced that it aims to raise $13.75 million by selling shares in a stegosaurus fossil.
content: With dinosaur fossils fetching millions of dollars at recent auctions, it was perhaps inevitable: A private company said Friday that it had set the date for a public offering that will allow investors to buy shares in a stegosaurus fossil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Andelman
title: Martial Solal, French Jazz Piano Virtuoso, Is Dead at 97
description: Mr. Solal, who also wrote music for films and symphony orchestras, was revered in Europe and hailed in the United States on his rare visits there.
content: Martial Solal, Europe’s pre-eminent jazz pianist, who recorded dozens of startlingly original albums in a career of almost three quarters of a century and who wrote scores for numerous films, including Jean-Luc Godard’s masterpiece “Breathless,” died on Thursday in Versailles, France. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Reveling in a Wry Storybook, Full of Characters
description: The choreographer Tess Dworman inhabits an assortment of people (and an ottoman) in her dance-theater work “Everything Must Go.”
content: Tess Dworman is rarely just Tess Dworman. This choreographer and dancer is a shape-shifter with a biting wit. She inhabits other people as if she were flipping through sketches and bringing them to life. You grasp who they are through Dworman’s delivery, an endearing mix of sharp and guileless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Sophia Lanman
title: TikTok’s Last Stand, Google’s Quantum Breakthrough and the Cult of Claude
description: “The president was given a very clear and easy opportunity to say, ‘Yes, I am going to save TikTok,’ and he absolutely did not say that.”
content: Last Friday, a panel of federal judges denied TikTok’s petition to overturn the law that could force the ban of the app in the United States. We walk through the judges reasoning and explain why TikTok’s First Amendment argument was unsuccessful. Then, Julian Kelly, the director of quantum hardware at Google Quantum AI, explains how close we are to quantum computers that can solve practical problems. Finally, we talk about a new sentiment sweeping Silicon Valley: affection for the chatbot Claude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: What Song Did You Discover, or Rediscover, in 2024?
description: We want to know why it resonated with you.
content: In a recent edition of The Amplifier newsletter, Lindsay Zoladz shared the music that shaped her year. She rediscovered a classic from the Smiths thanks to a karaoke party, dug into Neil Young’s back catalog after seeing him in concert, and revisited a Frank Sinatra standard because it reminded her of a cherished trip to Vermont.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: For Those Granted Clemency by White House, a Moment to Celebrate and Plan
description: Among those whose sentences were commuted was Rebecca Parrett, an Arizona woman who now hopes to travel to meet her great-grandchildren for the first time.
content: Early on Thursday morning, Rebecca Parrett received a phone call from her former hairdresser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Surprise, ‘We’re Getting Married Right Now!’
description: Daniel Howarth and Jonathan Marotto gathered their closest friends and family for a celebration that also happened to be their wedding.
content: When friends and family joined Daniel Alan Howarth and Jonathan Frank Marotto at a restaurant in Miami Beach on Nov. 20, they thought they were there to celebrate the couple’s recent wedding at the Miami Beach courthouse earlier that day. But they hadn’t actually gotten married.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Profile of the C.E.O. Killing Suspect, and Tech Giants Give to Trump Fund

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Alice Callahan, Alex Stern, Sydney Harper, Rikki Novetsky, Olivia Natt, Michael Simon Johnson, Lisa Chow, Chris Haxel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: A Turning Point for Ultraprocessed Foods
description: The wide-ranging category includes sodas, processed meats, many breakfast cereals, snack foods and frozen meals.
content: A new study has found that nearly three-quarters of American adults are now obese or overweight, and there’s growing concern — among politicians, scientists and consumers — about one potential culprit: ultraprocessed foods.Alice Callahan, a nutrition and health reporter for The New York Times, discusses how these foods came to be such a big part of what we eat, and why that’s so hard to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Breaking the Cycle of Childhood Poverty in New York
description: Children’s Aid provides essential help with food and housing for families in New York City, where tens of thousands of children live in poverty.
content: New York State has one of the worst child poverty rates in the country. In New York City, one in every four children lives in poverty. Tens of thousands of children are not getting enough food to eat, and their families are struggling to make rent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Syrians Celebrated a New Chapter
description: Also, McKinsey will pay $650 million in an opioid settlement. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: Jubilant crowds gathered today in cities across Syria for the first Friday Prayer since rebels toppled President Bashar al-Assad. Elsewhere in the country, Russia’s military appeared to be packing up equipment at a critical base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis N. Rieder
title: A Broken System Is No Excuse
description: Our broken system can test us, but it shouldn’t break our morals.
content: When Brian Thompson was shot to death, something strange — and disturbing — happened: The gunman was lauded. Why? Because his victim was the C.E.O. of one of the largest health insurance companies in the country. And so the shooter, observers assumed, must be a victim of those companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Uber and Lyft Found a Loophole in a Driver Pay Law. Drivers Pushed Back.
description: As ride-hailing companies and labor unions each push New York City to amend its rules, drivers hurt by widespread app lockouts are struggling to make ends meet.
content: New York City was the first place in the United States to mandate minimum pay rates for drivers for companies like Uber and Lyft. But after the companies found a loophole that made it much harder for some drivers to get by, the city is looking to change its law, prompting dueling pressure campaigns as both sides seek to influence the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Tired of Tipping? Holidays May Be the Exception.
description: Consumers have said they are confused and frustrated with tipping expectations generally. But, one expert says, “people generally want to feel more generous around the holidays.”
content: The tradition of holiday tips to thank service workers endures, even as Americans have gotten tired of the regular requests for tips the rest of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Vora
title: Marriage, Baby and House, Though Not in That Order
description: Jocelyn Weigel and Zac Troughton matched on a dating app at the height of the pandemic, when both were lonely and looking for love.
content: When Jocelyn Kay Weigel and Zachary Perry Troughton were matched on Hinge in August 2020, they were both feeling lonely and seeking companionship. Though attuned to the risks of dating during the pandemic, it was clear to both that there was a connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: Six Childhood Scourges We’ve Forgotten About, Thanks to Vaccines
description: Most Americans, including doctors, have no memory of the devastating diseases that routinely threatened children until the 1960s.
content: Some of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s picks for the government’s top health posts have expressed skepticism about the safety of childhood vaccines. It’s a sentiment shared by a growing number of parents, who are choosing to skip recommended shots for their children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkey Emerges as a Big Winner in the Wake of al-Assad’s Ouster
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had long worked with the rebels who overtook Damascus. His influence over Syria is now likely to grow.
content: In the messy aftermath of the fall of the Assad regime in Syria, many questions remain about the country’s future, but one thing is clear: Turkey has emerged as a winner, with more influence than ever over the rebels who now control most of Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Media Moguls Set the Stage for Deal Mania
description: Comcast and Warner Bros. Discovery are rearranging their businesses for mergers and acquisitions. Experts say the next year could transform the media industry.
content: The people in charge of the world’s biggest media companies are setting the stage for a flurry of deal making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clare de Boer
title: This Chef’s Stunning Christmas Spread Is Unexpectedly Effortless
description: Anchored by juicy braised duck and finished with an unforgettable family-size crème brûlée, this menu from Clare de Boer will have everyone talking.
content: A feast is only a feast if both effort and bounty are shared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Michael Rothfeld
title: Eric Adams’s Advisers Are Trying to Get Him a Trump Inauguration Ticket
description: Members of the Democratic mayor’s team have put out the word to New York Republicans that he is interested in attending Donald J. Trump’s swearing-in.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has spent weeks inching closer to President-elect Donald J. Trump, flouting the concerns of many fellow Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Lean Supplies Trouble Lovers of Stout
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 13, 2024
content: “If you come in and order Pepsi and we don’t have it, we’ll give you Coke. There’s no real substitute for Guinness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Conan O’Brien’s Parents Die 3 Days Apart
description: Thomas O’Brien, an epidemiologist, and Ruth O’Brien, a lawyer, juggled successful careers with raising six children, including the comedy star.
content: The parents of Conan O’Brien, the longtime late-night television host and a star in the comedy world, died this week within days of one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: America’s Health Care System Needs Better Economics, Not Bullets
description: If only fixing it were as easy as finding someone to blame.
content: I can predict when one of my newsletters is going to divide a lot of readers. This is one of them. I’m going to argue that the problem with health insurance and the health care system overall is misaligned incentives. It is, in other words, a problem of structure, not any individual’s morality. Evil should not be part of the conversation. Nor — and I hate to have to say this — should killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Money in Suitcase
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Miley Cyrus Gives Showgirl Pathos, and 8 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Benjamin Booker, Julien Baker and Torres, and more.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Isgur
title: I Don’t Want a Pardon From Biden. None of Us Should.
description: We should show that we trust the fairness of the justice system.
content: In his 2023 book, “Government Gangsters,” Kash Patel, whom Donald Trump says he intends to nominate as the next director of the F.B.I., named 60 people whom he classified as “members of the executive branch deep state” — a “cabal of unelected tyrants” who posed “the most dangerous threat to our democracy.” Mr. Patel has since said that the incoming Trump administration must deal with the “deep state,” be it “criminally or civilly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: What Is (or Was) ‘Perks Culture’?
description: After mass layoffs and a pivot to A.I., the tech industry has been scaling back on the splashy and quirky benefits it had become known for.
content: A deep-tissue massage. Housekeeping and laundry services. A haircut after lunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Oksana Parafeniuk
title: Dating on the Front Line: Ukrainian Women Travel to Keep Love Alive
description: Many women are making dangerous trips to places where loved ones are fighting Russian forces. “We try to imagine that for these two days, there is no war,” one said.
content: Everything happened so fast. On their first in-person date, they went to see a play, and she whispered in his ear, “I think I’ve fallen in love with you.” Soon after, they were married. And shortly after that, he was sent back to the front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: A Very Senatorial Goodbye: Nostalgia, Legacy and Gratitude, Live on C-SPAN
description: The farewell address is a Senate ritual that reflects the culture of the chamber, which prizes tradition, individual relationships, lofty debates and long-winded speeches.
content: The way Senator Joe Manchin III tells it, the senatorial bashes he hosted on his beloved houseboat Almost Heaven were so good they could inspire the most liberal of Democrats and the most conservative of Republicans to start writing bills together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Louis Nelson, Designer of Korean War Mural, Dies at 88
description: A designer of signage and product packaging, he was best known for his work on the 164-foot mural wall at the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington.
content: Louis Nelson, an industrial designer who conceived a central element of the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington, drawing on his experiences as a peacetime Army officer and art student when he encountered veterans of the Korean conflict, died on Dec. 4 in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Wendy Dorr, Diane Wong and Javier C. Hernández
title: At the Piano With Jon Batiste
description: How the artist found the blues in Beethoven
content: Jon Batiste, the Grammy Award-winning composer, television personality and jazz and R&B artist recently released “Beethoven Blues,” his first classical album. Batiste blends Beethoven’s most familiar compositions, like “Für Elise” and the Fifth Symphony, with improvised jazz, blues and funk, finding “soul” in the composer’s work. Javier Hernández, a classical music reporter, sits down at the piano with Batiste for an interview and a music lesson at Electric Lady Studios in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: What Is Venture Capital Now Anyway?
description: The opposing paths taken by two powerful firms — Benchmark and Andreessen Horowitz — embody a profound debate about the future of an industry that funds and fosters American innovation.
content: Three decades ago, five men formed a venture capital firm on Sand Hill Road in Silicon Valley with a simple pitch: Small is beautiful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: First Pass Friday, or How I Made My Way Into a Tough Puzzle
description: Ryan Patrick Smith’s crossword put up quite a fight, but there is always a way to win.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to First Pass Friday, an occasional Wordplay column in which I show you my first few passes through the clue list. This serves two purposes: It provides encouragement for those who are just starting to solve the harder, end-of-the-week puzzles, and it proves to those who have finished the crossword that they are much smarter than I am.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI’s Sam Altman to Donate $1 Million to Trump’s Inaugural Fund
description: Mr. Altman and OpenAI have recently hired key executives who previously worked for the Clinton, Obama and Biden administrations.
content: OpenAI said on Friday that its chief executive, Sam Altman, was planning to donate $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, joining a number of tech companies and executives who are working to improve their relationships with Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vera Brosgol
title: Two’s a Crowd: 3 New Chapter Books Sing the Praises of Me Time
description: The protagonists of “A Day With Mousse,” “Little Shrew” and “Lone Wolf Goes to School” feel happiest on their own.
content: “Hell is — other people!,” as a character in Sartre’s one-act play “No Exit” famously exclaims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: For Two Indian Movie Stars, a Love Language Expressed in Telugu
description: Sobhita Dhulipala and Naga Chaitanya Akkineni bonded over their South Indian roots and a shared language that felt like home. They married in an “intimate” ceremony of 300.
content: Sobhita Dhulipala was unable to attend the 52nd International Emmy Awards, where the Hindi-language television show she starred in, “The Night Manager,” was nominated for best drama series. But she had a good reason: She was getting ready to marry her fellow actor, Naga Chaitanya Akkineni.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Charlie Savage and Eileen Sullivan
title: Patel Distorts Justice Dept. Benghazi Inquiry, Inflating His Role
description: Donald J. Trump’s pick to be the next F.B.I. director has both exaggerated his importance in the government’s criminal inquiry into the 2012 attack and misleadingly distorted its conduct and results.
content: Kash Patel, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to be F.B.I. director, often burnishes his credentials as a former prosecutor even as he portrays law enforcement agencies as an inept and politicized “deep state.” A critical piece of that narrative is the investigation into the 2012 attack on a diplomatic compound and a C.I.A. annex in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans.

title: The Messy Modern Music Business, According to Larry Jackson
description: On this week’s episode of Popcast, an interview with a record label veteran who has worked closely with Whitney Houston, Drake, Chief Keef and Lana Del Rey.
content: The music executive Larry Jackson, a founder of the entertainment company Gamma, has seen several sea changes in the recording business from different vantages over different eras of disruption.

author: By Ben Hubbard and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Joy Buoys Syria’s First Friday Prayers Since Assad Ouster, but Hardships Loom
description: In an impoverished, war-ravaged country, the first prayers after the fall of a brutal regime drew jubilant crowds, even in areas seen as regime strongholds.
content: Jubilant crowds gathered in cities across Syria for the first Friday Prayers since rebels toppled President Bashar al-Assad, including at the historic Umayyad Mosque in the capital, where civilians and fighters worshiped side by side and joyful chants erupted over the collapse of a long authoritarian dynasty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Ordered to Sit for Deposition in ABC News Defamation Suit
description: The deposition, if it is held as scheduled next week, will take place even as the president-elect is in the throes of defending cabinet nominees and putting together his administration.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump was ordered by a federal judge on Friday to sit for a deposition next week in the defamation lawsuit he brought this spring against ABC News and one of its anchors, George Stephanopoulos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Dorfman
title: The Best Book Covers of 2024
description: A Book Review art director selects the book jackets that made a compelling impression.
content: If most book cover designs are conceived as quick-to-metabolize marketing tools, a great one can make the reader do a double take in slow motion. A good first impression is, of course, the goal: to elicit curiosity and excitement before you’ve even picked the book off a shelf. But a great cover can fortify itself in our consciousness, resonating more deeply as we absorb the text within, ideally prompting a second impression after we finish reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaleigh Rogers
title: Most Americans Say They Have Good Health Insurance, Polls Show
description: Many have encountered problems with their coverage, but the recent rage on social media is only part of the picture of Americans’ views on health care.
content: Americans voted last month in an election that polls showed was largely about the economy. Less than 1 percent of likely voters ranked health care as their top issue.

description: A person familiar with the incident said the former House speaker, 84, had tripped going down stairs at a palace. People close to her said she had fractured her hip in the fall.
content: Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi was hospitalized on Friday after being injured while traveling abroad on a bipartisan congressional delegation to Luxembourg, a spokesman said on Friday.

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Timothée Chalamet Joins a Rarified Club of Actors Singing in Musical Biopics
description: The actor’s vocals so impressed the film’s director that he used the live recordings, instead of prerecorded ones. Here’s a look at other actors who have hit their own high notes.

content: Charles Handy, a writer, social philosopher and management theorist who presciently imagined a brave new corporate world where employees worked remotely, jobs were outsourced and workers had “portfolio careers,” working for themselves and contracting their skills to companies, died on Friday at his home in London. He was 92.

Because what could be more fun than confining your characters somewhere they cannot escape, and then slowly tormenting them as the plot unfolds?

content: Years ago, when I was struggling with addiction, I would occasionally (once a month or less) engage in sex work to help make ends meet. This was voluntary — no one made me do anything I didn’t want to do — but it’s still uncomfortable for me to think about sometimes. I always used protection during these encounters and continue to get screened for S.T.D.s regularly. If anything, I think I’m slightly less likely than the general population is to pass anything on.

title: Critics Complain That Italy’s Government Is Interfering in the Arts
description: Italy’s culture ministry dismissed experts preparing an exhibition on Futurism and put in its own appointees, who created a show that seems to glorify the Mussolini years.
content: Earlier this month, hundreds thronged to Rome’s National Gallery of Modern and Contemporary Art for the highly anticipated opening of a major exhibition on Futurism, arguably Italy’s most notable contribution to 20th-century art. Coming on the heels of cubism, Futurist art broke with the past to capture the movement and dynamism of the modern age. Yet with its nationalistic and warmongering rhetoric, Futurism is also intertwined, in part, with Mussolini’s Fascist regime.

content: I have a simple rule of thumb when assessing the potential instability of Middle Eastern countries. They come in just two varieties: countries that implode and countries that explode. That is, countries where, when central control collapses, the ruined pillars fall inside their borders, and countries where, when central control collapses, the blast radius of all the political shrapnel extends far and wide.

content: On the day in 1955 that Jonas Salk’s polio vaccine was pronounced “80 to 90 percent effective” against the form of the disease that caused paralysis, 500 medical scientists and 150 reporters jammed into an auditorium at the University of Michigan for the announcement.
